data.text: Contents
Introduction

The aim of any job evaluation system is to ensure parity of salaries across all groups of staff, and it is the policy of the Trust that all jobs, except for medical posts which are covered by the provisions of national terms and conditions, are evaluated to determine the appropriate pay band.

The Trust has determined that the national NHS Job Evaluation system is the most appropriate system to underpin the local pay arrangements therefore this policy should be read in conjunction with the NHS Job Evaluation Handbook, the latest version can be found on the following link: NHS Job Evaluation Handbook (nhsemployers.org) at https://www.nhsemployers.org/pay-pensions-and-reward/job- evaluation/job-evaluation-handbook.
It is essential that the job evaluation process is supported by a robust policy framework that promotes fairness and equity and is transparent to staff. This policy document sets out this framework.
This policy applies to all permanent, fixed term and temporary posts, with the exception of those associated with Medical and Dental staff, and Executive and Non- Executive Directors.
The policy does not need to be applied where there are straight replacements for existing posts that have already been aligned to a pay band.
Where the term “job evaluation” is used in this policy, it refers to both job evaluation and job matching.
Purpose
The purpose of this document is to:
Ensure that the job evaluation process is carried out in a fair, objective and consistent manner in accordance with the national Agenda for Change (AFC) job evaluation process.

Provide a process on how posts are banded/ grouped within the agreed band under Agenda for change on the basis of a combination of 16 factors in accordance with the Job Evaluation Handbook, at https://www.nhsemployers.org/pay-pensions-and-reward/job-evaluation/job- evaluation-handbook.
Set out the grounds on which staff can request a review of their banding and the process by which they should do so.
Promote effective partnership working between management and Staffside at all levels.
Definitions

table_items.text: Any member of staff who sits on an evaluation/matching panel and is not representing an accredited trade union on the panel.
Any member of staff who sits on an evaluation/matching panel and is representing an accredited trade union on the panel.
The handbook sets out the job evaluation scheme for the NHS as agreed by NHS employer and Staffside representatives for NHS non-medical staff.
The process where a job profile is matched against nationally agreed profiles as detailed in the NHS Job Evaluation Handbook.
A method of determining a pay band, based on an up to date job description and person specification, using a points based system as detailed in the NHS Job Evaluation Handbook

data.text: Role and responsibilities within the Trust
Joint Negotiating Committee has the duty to:
Annually monitor the operation of this policy.
Review this policy prior to its renewal da
Chief Executive

The Chief Executive has overall responsibility for ensuring that there is an effective process in place but day to day executive responsibility is delegated to the Director of Human Resources and Organisational Development.
Director of Human Resources and Organisational Development
The Director of Human Resources has executive responsibility for the implementation and monitoring of this policy.
Heads of Service/Clinical or Corporate Director
The Head of Service/Clinical or Corporate Director must ensure that the policy is implemented within their service areas.
Line Managers

Managers are responsible for ensuring that all job descriptions within their remit have been banded in line with this policy and process. They must ensure that the job descriptions are written to meet the needs of the service and are produced on the Trust's template.
The line managers should ensure that all job descriptions are banded prior to recruitment and should respond to employee requests for re-banding.
Employee

Employees work in partnership with their manager to ensure that their job description is up to date and meets the needs of the service. Employees should agree to the content of the job description before submitting for re-banding.
Human Resources

Human Resources updates the Trust's Job Evaluation Policy and provides support and guidance to managers on implementation of the policy. Human Resources will initially assess the quality of the job description before sending it to the AFC Administrator for banding.
Agenda for Change (AFC) Administrator

The AFC administrator is to co-ordinate job descriptions for panel including: setting up panels and organising panel members, ensuring that necessary forms have been completed, that the necessary documentation is available for panel members, updating the internal systems and informing managers of the outcome.
The administrator is to develop the appropriate documentation to support this policy and process and ensure that panels are conducted in line with NHS Employers guidelines.
Reasons for evaluation
Existing Posts
Those posts that have significantly changed since the previous evaluation to the extent that the manager or employee believes it may affect the pay band can be submitted for re-evaluation.
On submission of the updated job description and person specification the post holder confirmed by the line manager must provide evidence showing which factors of the post have changed.

An employee retains the right to request their role be re-evaluated if they believe it has changed to an extent that it affects their current pay band, however the content of the job description and person specification should be agreed with the line manager before submission to the job evaluation co-ordinator via the Associate Director.

Where agreement cannot be reached on the job description and person specification, the areas of disagreement should be highlighted so that the panel can assess how relevant they are to the outcome of the evaluation.
New Posts
In the event that a new role is created within the Trust, it will need to be evaluated so that the appropriate banding is applied prior to advertising.

A new post for job evaluation must be submitted by a Line Manager for evaluation with the relevant job description, person specification and organisation structure chart for that department/directorate. The request will need to be authorised by the relevant Service Associate Director.

If a post is submitted for job evaluation as a new post, but it is identified that it is not new or unique to the Trust, or can be clustered to an existing Trust post due to similarities, then the Job Evaluation Co-ordinator will confirm the outcome of the previous evaluation or clustered post, including the pay band.
Requests for evaluation
All requests for job evaluation should be forwarded to the AFC Administrator via the Associate Director of HR for approval. The following documents should be sent:
Job evaluation request form (Appendix 1)
New job description and person specification (Appendix 2)
Old job description and person specification where applicable
Structure chart
Job description and person specification

Job evaluation will be carried out on the basis of a comprehensive and up to date job description and person specification prepared on Mid and South Essex NHS Foundation Trust templates. It should be prepared by the line manager with guidance from Human Resources where required.
To ensure consistency, any request for a post to be put through the job evaluation process must be presented in a common format as shown in appendix
National Profiles
A number of possible national profiles can be submitted to the panel by the managers and/or employees for consideration by the panel.
Job Analysis Questionnaire

Where there is no national profile for a post or an existing matched post in the Trust as a possible cluster, then a job analysis questionnaire may need to be completed by the post holder and line manager before being submitted for evaluation.

For vacant posts, where there is no national profile, the role will be subject to desktop evaluation for recruitment purposes and the post holder will be asked to complete a job analysis questionnaire once they have been in post for at least 3 months.
Job evaluation panels
Panel Composition

All posts will normally be evaluated in partnership by both management and staff side representatives. Each panel will ideally consist of at least 3 members but should endeavour to have 4 members (2 from each side) and to promote development, learning panels will consist of 5 members. For panels of 3 these will be made up of 1 member from each side then an additional member from either management or Staffside depending on availability. Panel members will receive training in the job evaluation process by someone that has undertaken the national job evaluation training.

All panels should be convened with all members present regardless of the panel taking place in person or virtually. Panels should be representative of the organisation as a whole. Panellists will be fully and appropriately trained in the job evaluation process.
Frequency
The matching panel will meet as frequently as required on dates to be arranged by the job evaluation co-ordinator.

All documentation, as detailed in the previous sections, should be submitted to the job evaluation co-ordinator no later than 7 calendar days before the panel are due to meet. Requests will be allocated to the next available panel on a first come first serve basis. There will be a maximum four week turn around for job evaluation. Managers will need to consider these timescales before planning and advertising the job.
External panel members/suppliers

In exceptional circumstances for example for large scale organisational change or where staff side and/or management side panels cannot be constituted within 4 weeks, the Trust will use an external supplier such as another NHS Trust or external organisation who has evaluators that have undertaken national training to match or evaluate new posts that have been submitted for evaluation. If this is the case, the job evaluation co-ordinator will advise the manager that this is the case and will provide timescales.
Consistency checking
The aim of consistency checking is to avoid local grading anomalies that are inconsistent with similar jobs elsewhere.

All jobs, that are evaluated, are subjected to consistency checking before the outcome is released to the managers in accordance with Section 14 of the NHS Job Evaluation Handbook. Consistency checking panel members consists of management and Staffside representative and must be different to those who were on the initial panel.
7.13 Any disagreement on outcome of the consistency will be reviewed by the external supplier providing appropriate information on areas of disagreement.
Job evaluation outcomes

The job evaluation co-ordinator will advise the hiring/line manager of the pay band as a result of the job evaluation of the post. Jobs will not be re-evaluated unless there is a significant change to the responsibilities or accountabilities that may affect the pay band.
Evaluated Higher

Where the evaluated post has been evaluated higher than the existing post holder then salary progression to the appropriate revised pay band and salary for the existing/joint post holder should take place and be implemented by the appropriate line manager in accordance with the Trust's Terms and Conditions.
Evaluated Lower

Where the evaluated post is evaluated lower than the existing post holder then progression to the appropriate revised pay band and salary should take place and be implemented by the appropriate line manager in accordance with the Trust's Terms and Conditions. Pay protection arrangements should apply as detailed in the MSE Organisational Change Policy.
Where the evaluation is for a vacant post, this will be advertised at the revised pay band.
Implementation Date
Any change to a pay band as a result of job evaluation or job matching will be implemented from the date the post holder and manager agree the new job description.
Incremental Dates

If staff members receive a pay increase as a result of job evaluation, the step date will change to the effective date of the pay change. If there is no pay increase, then the step date will remain unchanged.
Financial Implications
Where job evaluation takes place on an individual post level, the financial implications would normally be met through the departmental budget.

Where job evaluation takes place on a grade / occupation / departmental level (e.g. to support organisational change) the pay outcomes need to be identified as part of the business planning process or through the project proposal.

The financial implications of such exercises need to be clearly understood and would involve the budget holder in any discussions. Such financial implications, where agreed, must be met by the appropriate budget holder, and will not be met through any central reserve or surplus.
In all cases Finance need to be made aware of any changes to ensure the financial implications are planned.
Appeals process

In line with section  of the Job Evaluation Handbook there is no recourse to appeal a nationally profiled post but there is a right to a review on the grounds that a post does not match the national profile. Staff or managers who have any outstanding concerns about local consistency should submit an appeal using the MSE Appeals Policy. The appeal will be carried out based on the protocols set out in the Job Evaluation Handbook.
Training requirements
Human Resources will ensure appropriate training is available to those involved in the job evaluation process.

This policy has been reviewed and approved by the Employee Relations team and will be implemented with immediate effect from its agreement date. This document will be available electronically on the Trust Intranets. Advice and support on the implementation of this policy is available via the Employee Relations Team.
Equality impact assessment

This policy has been the subject of an Equality Impact Assessment. The outcome of the assessment demonstrates that no-one as a consequence of this policy is placed at a disadvantage over others. The Equalities, Diversity and Inclusion Manager can
provide specialist advice on equality issues in relation to implementation of this policy and can be contacted via HR (Refer to Appendix 2).
